awd_titl_txt: Low Energy Electrodynamics in Solids with Strong Electron Correlations
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
In many newly discovered materials, there is a particularly strong interaction between the electron charges or between the magnetic moments leading to new phenomena at relatively low temperatures. Examples include superconductivity - ability to conduct electricity without any loss - or other complex macroscopically ordered phases of charge and spin distributions. Understanding the unconventional properties of these materials presents a great intellectual challenge, and enhancement of transition temperatures of such macroscopically ordered states is critical to developing new technologies. This project investigates the basic mechanisms responsible for unconventional properties of strongly interacting materials by scattering light (i.e., "photons") from the materials while tuning the materials' properties through their novel phases. The goals of this project are to better understand the conditions responsible for the emerging properties, and to assist in development of novel materials with enhanced functionality. 

Technical Abstract:
Interaction between electrons in "strongly correlated materials" is associated with many scientifically important and technologically useful phenomena, including superconductivity and exotically ordered charge and spin phases. This project applies the advances in low energy spectroscopy to characterize these extraordinary self-organized electronic phases, determine the condition under which they are formed, identify the underlying microscopic mechanisms, and test the relevant theories. This project also provides broad training to postdoc and undergraduate students in low-temperature high resolution magneto-optical spectroscopy.

por.por_cntn:
Interaction between electrons in "strongly correlated materials" is associated with many scientifically important and technologically useful phenomena, including superconductivity and many other exotically ordered charge and spin phases. In this project advances in low energy spectroscopy were applied to create knowledge base for deeper experimental and theoretical understanding of complex many-body phenomena in solids; specifically, to characterize extraordinary self-organized electronic phases, determine the condition under which they are formed, identify the underlying microscopic mechanisms, and test the relevant theories. 

The outcomes of research were broadly disseminated via research publications, press releases and conference presentations. During the proposal funding cycle 20 research papers where published (which include publications in PNAS, in PRL, in npj Quantum Materials, to name a few) and many presentations were made at national and international meetings. Among others, topics include:
-Chiral electronic excitations in the quasi-two-dimensional Rashba system BiTeI.
-Crystal-field excitations and quadrupolar fluctuations of 4f-electron systems studied by polarized light scattering.
-Charge density wave order in the Kagome metals.
-Critical charge fluctuations and lattice dynamics in excitonic insulators.
-Quadrupolar charge dynamics in pnictide superconductors.
-Effects of magnetism on lattice dynamics in pnictide superconductors.
-Relations between superconductivity and phonon self-energy effects in pnictide superconductors.
-Excitations in frustrated magnets.
-Chiral surface excitons in topological insulators.
-Chiral spin modes on the surface of a topological insulators. 

This project also provided broad training to postdoc and undergraduate students in low-temperature high resolution magneto-optical spectroscopy. Two (2) PhD students graduated during the proposal funding cycle. 

H.-H. Kung's Ph.D. thesis was recognized by the prestigious 2019 Northeast Association of Graduate Schools (NAGS) Outstanding Doctoral Dissertation Award, the 2019 Springer Theses Award, and the 2020 APS Richard L. Greene Dissertation Award in Experimental Condensed Matter or Materials Physics, to name a few. A female postdoc, Weilu Zhang, has accepted a faculty position in Sophia University, Tokyo.
